File.Title: Efferent Connections of the Substantia Innominata in the Rat

Abstract.S: ABSTRACT

The efferent connections of the substantia innominata (SI) were investigated employing the anterograde axonal transport of Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) and the retrograde transport of wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP).
The projections of the SI largely reciprocate the afferent connections described by Grove (J Comp.
NeuroL 277:315-346, '88) and thus further distinguish a dorsal and a ventral division in the SI.

Efferents from both the dorsal and ventral divisions of the SI descend as far caudal as the ventral tegmental area, substantia nigra, and peripeduncular area, but projections to pontine and medullary structures appear to originate mainly from the dorsal SI.

Within the amygdala and hypothalamus, which receive widespread innervation from the SI, the dorsal SI projects preferentially to the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis; the lateral, basolateral, and central nuclei of the amygdala; the lateral preoptic area; paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus; and certain parts of the lateral hypothalamus, prominently including the perifornical and caudolateral zones described previously.

The ventral SI projects more heavily to the medial part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis; the anterior amygdaloid area; a ventromedial amygdaloid region that includes but is not limited to the medial nucleus; the lateral and medial preoptic areas; and the anterior hypothalamus.
Modest projections reach the lateral hypothalamus, with at least a slight preference for the medial part of the region, and the ventromedial and arcuate hypothalamic nuclei.
Both SI divisions appear to innervate the dorsomedial and posterior hypothalamus and the supramammillary region.

In the thalamus, the subparafascicular, gustatory, and midline nuclei receive a light innervation from the SI, which projects more densely to the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus and the reticular nucleus.

Cortical efferents from at least the midrostrocaudal part of the SI are distributed primarily in piriform, infralimbic, prelimbic, anterior cingulate, granular and agranular insular, perirhinal, and entorhinal cortices as well as in the main and accessory olfactory bulbs.

The cells of origin for many projections arising from the SI were identified as cholinergic or noncholinergic by combining the retrograde transport of WGA-HRP with histochemical and immunohistochemical procedures to demonstrate acetylcholinesterase activity or choline acetyltransferase immunoreactivity.
Most of the descending efferents of the SI appear to arise primarily or exclusively from noncholinergic cells.

Overall, the subcortical projections of the dorsal division of the SI were found to be strikingly reminiscent of those reported previously for two adjoining structures: the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and the central nucleus of the amygdala.

A second tissue continuum with common subcortical efferents appears to be formed by the medial part of the bed nucleus, ventral SI, and the rostra1 parts of both the medial nucleus of the amygdala and an amygdaloid region that lies ventral to the central nucleus and dorsal to the cortical nuclei (Krettek and Price: J.

Introduction.S: The substantia innominata (SI) is an amorphous region of the mammalian basal forebrain that stretches along the ventral aspect of the corpus striatum.

An extension of the globus pallidus (GP), the ventral pallidum (VP) of Heirner and Wilson ('754 has been shown to occupy roughly the rostra1 third of the region as historically defined (Heimer and Wilson, '75; Switzer et al., '82; Haber and Nauta, '83), and the term "substantia innominata" is now generally reserved for the area caudal to the VP (Paxinos and Watson, '82, '86).
The connectivity of this comparatively poorly characterized basal forebrain district is the subject of the present pair of companion studies.

The first of these two studies showed that the afferent connections of the SI strongly resemble those of the amygdala and that innervation is provided by widespread cell groups in many of the main subdivisions of the brain (Grove, '88).

Further, the distribution of fibers afferent to the SI (de Olmos, '72; de Olmos et al., '85; Grove, '88) and of certain neurochemical and histochemical markers (de Olmos, '72; de Olmos et al., '85; Lind et al., '85; Grove, '88) indicates that the SI, which appears uniform in material stained to reveal Nissl substance or myelin, is in fact organized into a dorsal and a ventral division.

To date, the efferent connections of the SI have not been examined in a single comprehensive study, nor have previous investigations noted whether projections with different targets arise from different subregions within the SI.

Of the known projections of the SI, those to the amygdala and cerebral cortex, originating from both cholinergic and noncholinergic neurons, have received the greatest recent attention (Lehmann et al., '80; Big1 et al., '82; Woolf and Butcher, '82; Grove et al., '83; McKinney et al., '83; Mesulam et al., '83a,b; Rye et al., '84b; Saper, '84; Carlsen et al., '85; Luiten et al., '85, '87; Fisher et al., '86; Woolf et al., '86).

Subcortical projections from the SI have been suggested in retrograde tracing studies of the afferent connections of several structures. including the thalamus (Young et al., '84; Levey et al., '87; Russchen et al., '871, ventra'i tegmental area Phillipson, '79), and dorsomedial medulla (Schwaber et al., '82).

Finally, efferents from the VP and adjacent SI to the hypothalamus, midbrain, and pons have been identified with both electrophysiological and anterograde tracing techniques (Swanson et al., '84; Haber et al., '85; Mogenson et al., '85).

Because much information regarding the efferent connections of the SI is still lacking, it is unclear how, or whether, the well-known cholinergic and noncholinergic projections from the SI to the cortex and amygdala are integrated into a more comprehensive set of the region's efferent connections.

Indeed, it might be suggested that the cholinergic cells in the SI represent an invading cell population, also distributed in the GP, nucleus of the diagonal band, and medial septum, a population whose connections could be unrelated to those of the SI as a whole.
However, some evidence suggests that the cholinergic cell group may participate in the afferent circuitry of other neurons in the SI (for review see Grove, '88).
Thus, the direct and indirect involvement of this cell group in the other efferent connections of the SI is worth further investigation.

In the present study, both the cortical and subcortical projections of the SI were investigated, employing the anterograde axonal transport of PHA-L (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84) and the retrograde transport of WGA-HRP.

The cells of origin for many projections arising from the SI were further identified as cholinergic or noncholinergic by combining the retrograde transport of WGA-HRP with histochemical and immunohistochemical procedures to locate acetylcholinesterase activity or choline acetyltransferase immunoreactivity.
Findings from the present study suggested three main generalizations.
First, the projections of the SI generally reciprocate the afferent connections described by Grove ('88).
As a consequence, a dorsal and a ventral division can be distinguished within the SI on the basis of both afferent and efferent connections.
Second, the efferent projections of the SI, like its afferent connections, strongly resemble those of neighboring components of the amygdala.

This similarity embraces not only efferents to caudal brainstem sites as previously reported (Schwaber et al., '82; Holstege et al., '85) but appears to incorporate virtually the entire set of SI projections.
Third, cholinergic cells in the SI do not seem to contribute significantly to most of the descending efferents of the region.

Nonetheless, several observations indicate that the cholinergic cell group in the SI may play an integral part in the overall efferent circuitry of the region rather than maintaining a wholly distinct set of projections.
For example, findings described below suggest that several noncholinergic projections from the SI lead indirectly over their subcortical targets to the cortex.
If so, the region's cholinergic corticopetal efferents may be viewed as part of a set of direct and indirect pathways leading - to the cortical mantle.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
For all experiments in the present study, adult female albino rats (CD strain) were obtained from Charles River Laboratories.

During surgical procedures and before transcardial perfusion of fixatives the animals were deeply anesthetized with Chloropent, a veterinary anesthetic containing chloral hydrate and pentobarbital (obtained previously from Ft.
Dodge Labs, but no longer available from this source).
Anterograde tracing experiments
In nine rats, PHA-L deposits were placed either in the 91 or in the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band (NHDB) (cases RPSI1-3 and RPDB1-6).

Additionally available for comparison were eight cases described in a previous report (Grove, '88) in which PHA-L deposits had been made adjacent to the SI in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (cases RPBNS2, RPGP4) and amygdala (cases RPAA1, RPAB1, RPACE8, RPBLS, RPBM1, RPBM3) (Grove, '88, Figs. 8, 9).
PHA-L, obtained from Vector Labs, was reconstituted and injected into the brain as previously described (Grove, '88).

After 4-8 days, the rats were perfused transcardially with 50 ml of saline, followed by fixative (up to 500 ml in 15-20 minutes) consisting of 2% paraformaldehyde and 0.1% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4.
The brains were stored in phosphate buffer, and sectioned at 50 pm into six series with an Oxford Vibratome.
PHA-L was then localized in two series of sections from each brain with a peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) procedure (Grove, '88).
One of the two series stained for PHA-L was counterstained with Cresyl Violet.

A third series from each brain was processed to reveal both PHA-L and choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) in the same sections, and a fourth was processed to locate met-enkephalin immunoreactivity (ENK-IR) (see Grove, '88).
Rabbit anti-ENK antiserum was donated by Dr.
R.
Elde.
Retrograde tracing experiments

In a total of 30 animals, injections of wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) were centered in the nucleus accumbens, amygdala, lateral hypothalamus, mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus, habenular nucleus, substantia nigra, ventral tegmental area, peripeduncular area, dorsal raphe, parabrachial nucleus, dorsomedial medulla, or neocortex.
Several of these injection sites are illustrated in Figure 7.
WGA-HRP (Sigma) was prepared and injected into the brain as described previously (Grove, '88).

Twenty-four to 72 hours after surgery the animals were perfused transcardially with 50 ml saline, followed by 500 ml of 2% paraformaldehyde and 0.1% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, and a final rinse of 100 ml3% sucrose in the same buffer.
After rinsing overnight in a 30% sucrose solution made up in phosphate buffer, the brains were cut on a freezing microtome into six series of 50-pm-thick transverse sections.

At least two of the six series of sections from each brain were processed to locate both WGA-HRP and a cholinergic marker: acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity in one series and choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) immunoreactivity in the other.

Intense AChE reactivity seen after pretreating animals with diisopropylfluorophosphate (DFP) is considered a reliable marker of cholinergic neurons in the GP, SI, and diagonal band-medial septum continuum (Levey et al., '83; Eckenstein and Sofroniew, '83).
Accordingly, 4-6 hours before perfusion, the rats were injected intramuscularly with DFP (1 mgkg) (Calbiochem) dissolved in peanut oil.
Sections to be double-labelled were processed to locate WGA-HRP with the TMB technique of de Olmos et al. ('781, and the TMB reaction product was stabilized to prevent fading (Rye et al., '84a).
Next, tissue sections were treated to reveal either AChE activity (Geneser-Jensen and Blackstad, '71) or ChAT immunoreactivity (following the same PAP procedure described by Grove, '88).
From each brain, control sections were prepared to demonstrate AChE activity or ChAT immunoreactivity alone.
Tissue sections processed only for WGA-HRP were counterstained with Neutral Red.

Two additional, unoperated rats were perfused transcardially, following the fixation procedure described by Baughman, Eckenstein, and their colleagues (see Graybiel et al., '86) to optimize staining for ChAT-IR fibers and their terminals within the basal forebrain.

Results.S: Cortical and subcortical projections of the substantia innominata

TTE.S: In case RPSI3, a PHA - L deposit was centered in the dorsal SI but intruded into the ventral division as well ( Fig .
The injection site did not spread into the amygdala , which is laterally contiguous with the SI .

About half of the PHA - L deposit lay in the most dorsal part of the SI , which , like the overlying GP , is marked by the presence of an enkephalin immunoreactive " woolly fiber " plexus ( Grove , ' 88 ) .
However , PHA - L did not appear to have been taken up by cells lying dorsal to the SI in the GP itself or by neurons in the VP .
Criteria used to delineate the SI from the adjacent GP and VP are discussed more fully in Grove ( ' 88 ) .

Briefly , the border between the SI and GP , marked by a dotted line in Figure 1, was drawn with reference to the dorsalmost extent of a dense band of ansa peduncularis fibers , whose passage characterizes the SI ( Grove , ' 88 ) .
Figure 1 illustrates the distribution of PHA - L - labelled fibers in this case .

Labelled axons displaying en passant and terminal varicosities ( putative synaptic boutons ) were found in numerous structures whose common characteristic is their position along the course of the ansa peduncularis ( AP ) or medial forebrain bundle ( MFB ) .
To reach the cortex , labelled fibers followed the AP or traveled in the internal capsule .

Most cortical fiber labelling was confined to areas surrounding or ventral to the rhinal sulcus : piriform cortex ( Fig . 1B - F ) , agranular and granular insular cortices ( divisions according to Paxinos and Watson , ' 86 ) ( Fig . 1A - C ) , and perirhinal and entorhinal cortex ( Fig . 1D - G ) .

However , at levels rostral to the genu of the corpus callosum ( Fig . lA ) , PHA - L - filled varicose axons also appeared along the medial face of the hemisphere in prelimbic , infralimbic , and rostral cingulate cortex ( divisions according to Beckstead , ' 79 ) .
Farther rostrally still , such fibers extended into the olfactory bulb .
In the amygdala , PHA - L - filled varicose axons spread out widely .

From the injection site , labelled fibers streamed through the dorsal and ventral SI into the rostral portion of the central nucleus ( Ace ) and the anterior amygdaloid area , only avoiding the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract ( NLOT ) ( Fig . 1C ) .
Numerous labelled varicose axons appeared in the medial segment of the central nucleus and in a region ventral to Ace ( Fig . lD , E ) .

Additional fibers crossed the lateral Ace , displaying few terminal varicosities , to reach the basolateral nucleus ( ABL ) and lateral nucleus ( AL ) , where moderate to dense terminal fields were apparent ( Fig . 1D - F ) .
The medial and cortical nuclei contained only sparse fiber labelling ( Fig . 1D - F ) .

Rostromedially directed fibers spread into the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( BNS ) , distributing almost entirely in its lateral sector ( divisions according to Paxinos and Watson , ' 82 ) ( Fig . 1B ) .

A few axons reaching more laterally traversed and terminated within the ventral pallidum and ventralmost striatum or coursed in and around the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band ( Fig .
lB,C).

In the hypothalamus , fibers spread into the lateral preoptic area ( Fig . lB ) , anterior hypothalamus ( Fig . 1C , D ) , paraventricular nucleus ( Fig . lD ) , and lateral ( Fig . lC - F ) , dorsal , and posterior hypothalamus ( Fig . 1F ) .

Although fiber labelling was widespread in the lateral hypothalamus , concentrations of PHA - L - filled varicose axons appeared in a perifornical zone of the lateral hypothalamus ( Fig . lE ) , largely lateral and dorsal to the fornix ; in a triangular , caudolateral zone adjacent to the subthalamic nucleus ( Fig . 1F ) ; and in a district ventral to the fornix ( Fig . lE , F ) .
Some PHA - L - filled fibers followed the ansa peduncularis dorsally from the hypothalamus into thalamic structures close to the midline .

Thus , at least sparse varicose fibers were labelled traversing the reuniens , rhomboid , and centromedial nuclei ( Fig . lD , E ) , and a denser terminal field was evident in the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus ( Fig . 1D ) .
In the lateral habenula labelled fibers formed small puffs in both the lateral and medial parts of the nucleus ( Fig . 1F ) .
Several axons were also labelled in a region transitional between the midline thalamus and the central gray of the midbrain ( Fig . 1F ) .

Elsewhere in the thalamus , PHA - L - filled varicose axons appeared in the reticular nucleus ( Fig . 1C - E ) , in the region termed the gustatory nucleus by Paxinos and Watson ( 86 ) , and just ventral to that in what may be the rostra1 tip of the parvocellular portion of the subparafascicular nucleus ( Grove , 88 ) ( Fig . 1F ) .
(The structure labelled %pf in Fig. 1F is the magnocellular part of the same nucleus.)

A moderate number of both smooth and varicose PHA - Lfilled fibers could be traced along the bifurcating route of the medial forebrain bundle through the midbrain and pons , appearing in the ventral tegmental area , linear nucleus of the raphe , substantia nigra pars compacta , peripeduncular area ( Fig . lG ) , pontine tegmentum ( including sparse varicose fiber labelling within cholinergic cell group Ch5 of Mesulam and his colleagues , 83b ) , central gray , and dorsal raphe nucleus ( Fig . 1H ) .
More caudally , PHA - L - filled varicose axons were evident in both the medial and lateral segments of the parabrachial nucleus and in the locus coeruleus and subcoeruleus ( Fig . 11 ) .

Perhaps because of a relatively short postinjection survival time , few labelled fibers could be followed caudal to the pons in this case : only one or two labelled fibers were seen in the region of the nucleus of the solitary tract and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus .

In a contrasting case , RPSIZ , an injection of PHA - L was centered in the ventral division of the SI , intruding into the dorsal SI , but not into the dorsalmost portion that is pervaded by ENK - IR woolly fibers and not spreading ventrally into the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band ( Fig . 1, bottom panel ) .
Axon labelling was evident in the same caudal brainstem regions as in case RPSI3 but appeared only very sparsely caudal to the ventral tegmental area .
In cortical structures fiber labelling was primarily confined to the entorhinal and piriform cortex ( Fig .
ZB-IS).

Sparse labelling appeared in the main olfactory bulb , and , unlike case RPSIS , a few PHA - L - filled fibers could also be traced to the accessory olfactory bulb ( AOB ) , where varicose axons were identified in the granule cell layer ( Fig . 2A ) .
The last finding appears consistent with previous observations by de Olmos and Beltramino (cited in de Olmos et al., 851.

In the amygdala , by contrast with case RPSIS , very little fiber labelling was found in the basolateral or lateral nu de Olmos and Beltramino noted that neurons retrogradely labelled from the AOB did not fill the entire SI but were confined to a band of tissue linking the medial nucleus of the amygdala with the medial part of the BNS .
clei.
In the central nucleus , significant numbers of PHA - Lfilled axons appeared only at its outer rim ( Fig . 2C ) .
Varicose fiber labelling was far more profuse , however , in a large ventromedial sector of the amygdala .

Numerous labelled axons appeared in the anterior amygdaloid area and in a region that lies ventral to the central nucleus , lateral to the medial nucleus and dorsal to the cortical nuclei ( Fig . 2C ) .
Most of this latter region has been left unlabelled in the present pair of studies (see Grove, 88).

It appears to include a district designated the intraamygdaloid division of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis by Paxinos and Watson ( 86 ) , and the anterior part of the basomedial nucleus as identified in the rat by other authors ( Krettek and Price , 78b ; de Olmos et al . , 85 ; Paxinos and Watson , 86 ) .
More caudally , varicose axon labelling continued into the amygdalohippocampal area and the posterior part of the basomedial nucleus ( Fig . 2D ) .
Additional moderately dense fiber labelling could be seen in the rostral part of the medial nucleus , diminishing caudally ( Fig . 2C ) .
A small number of PHA - L - filled varicose axons entered the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract and the cortical amygdaloid nuclei ( Fig . 2C , D ) .
A further marked contrast with case RPSIS was evident in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis .
Many PHA - Lfilled fibers appeared in medial and intermediate districts of the BNS , but few in the most lateral part of the nucleus ( Fig . 2B ) .
Additional fibers reached dorsal to the BNS into the lateral septum ( Fig . 2B ) .
In the rostral SI , PHA - L - filled axons occupied a relatively ventral position ( Fig . 2B ) .
As in case RPSIS , however , only a few labelled varicose fibers spread into the horizontal limb of the diagonal band , and still fewer in the nucleus of the vertical limb .
Rather more PHA - L - filled fibers coursed around the NHDB , particularly ventrally , close to the base of the brain ( Fig . 2B ) .

PHA - L deposits in the NHDB itself ( for example , cases RPDBl and RPDB5, Fig . 1 ) filled cell bodies and dendrites within this nucleus and disclosed that the dendrites of NHDB neurons may sometimes extend almost to the ventral surface of the brain .
Thus, axon terminals ventral to the NHDB proper could, nonetheless, potentially provide innervation to cells within that nucleus.
Denser axon labelling than in case RPSIS was evident in several parts of the medial hypothalamus .
This was most prominent in the medial preoptic area and anterior hypothalamus ( Fig . 2B ) .
However , a few PHA - L - filled sons entered the ventromedial and arcuate nuclei ( Fig . 2C , D ) , which were unlabelled in case RPSIS .
Denser fiber labelling than was seen in the previous case was also evident in the dorsomedial hypothalamus .
By contrast , several hypothalamic regions that contained many PHA - L - filled axons in case RPSI3 were comparatively sparsely labelled here .
Only sporadic labelled fibers could be identified in the paraventricular nucleus , although axon labelling appeared around and especially dorsal to this nucleus .
In the lateral preoptic area and lateral hypothalamus , PHA - L - filled fibers spread out diffusely , without apparent concentrations in the perifornical or caudolateral zones ( Fig . 2B - D ) .

As in case RPSI3, however , PHA - L - filled fibers reached through the dorsal and posterior hypothalamus ( Fig . 2C , D ) , to course along the midline thalamus into the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus ( Fig . 2C , D ) .

Results.S: Like the region referred to here as the SI , the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band contains cholinergic perikarya and is traversed by fibers of the ansa peduncularis .
Nonetheless , the NHDB is not conventionally included as part of the SI in the rat ( Paxinos and Watson , ' 82, ' 86 ) .

A thorough determination of the efferent connections of the NHDB was not attempted in the present study, since the nucleus is composed of several subdivisions (Zaborszky et al., '86a), not all of which were injected with PaA-L.

Available cases ( RPDB1 - RPDBG ) allowed , however , some comparisons of the efferent connections of the NHDB and the overlying SI amygdala , hypothalamus , and cauda . 1 with the cortex , brainstem .

TTE.S: In the case that displayed the most dense and widespread fiber labelling ( RPDBl ) , a large deposit of PHA - L was centered in the NHDB but spread into parts of the VP and rostra1 SI as well ( Fig . 1, bottom panel ) .
Several marked differences between RPDBl and previous cases appear, however, to be attributable to the involvement of the NHDH in the injection site.
The general distribution of labelled fibers in case RPDBl accorded quite well with that reported by Domesick ( ' 76 ) following tritiated amino acid injections into the NHDB .

In the amygdala , by contrast with cases RPSI2 and RPSI3, a profusion of PHA - L - filled fibers distinguished the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract ( Fig . 3A ) and the posterolateral cortical nucleus ( Fig . 3B ) .

More modest fiber labelling appeared in the anterior amygdaloid area , the anterior cortical , posteromedial cortical , and medial nuclei , and in the amygdaloid region that lies dorsal to the cortical nuclei and ventral to the central nucleus ( Fig . 3A , B ) .
In addition , a patch of richly varicose fibers was labelled in the ventromedial portion of the basolateral nucleus ( Fig . 3B ) .
However , such labelling may have been due to the spread of the PHA - L deposit into the rostral SI and ventral pallidum .
Consistent with this possibility , retrograde tracer injections confined to the basolateral nucleus fail to fill many cells in the NHDB ( Carlsen et al . , 85, and see below ) .
Further , no PHA - L - filled axons appeared in the basolateral nucleus when a small PHA - L deposit was confined to the NHDB ( case RPDB5, Fig . 1, bottom panel ) .

Suggesting a possible topographical organization in the projection from the SI to the basolateral nucleus , it is worth noting that a PHA - L deposit in the midcaudal SI ( case RPSI3, above ) labelled axons most densely in the lateral part of the basolateral nucleus .

Sparse to moderate axon labelling appeared in both the lateral and medial segments of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and in the lateral , dorsal , and posterior hypothalamus ( Fig . 3A , B ) .
Within the lateral hypothalamus , PHA - L - filled axons , both smooth and varicose , filled a triangular region medial to the zone marked in case RPSI3 ( compare Figs . 1F and 3B ) .
Many PHA - L - filled smooth and varicose axons were evident in the ventral tegmental area ( Fig . 3C ) and elsewhere along the route of the medial forebrain bundle through the midbrain and pons .

It cannot be discounted that some of this labelling - for example , part or all of that seen in the substantia nigra , pars compacta ( Fig . 3Cbwas due to the involvement of the ventral pallidum or rostral SI in the PHA - L injection site .
In the pons , however , the distribution of fiber labelling was strikingly different from that seen in previous cases and seems likely to have resulted from PHAL transport from the NHDB .

Varicose axons were labelled in the median , as well as dorsal , raphe , and in the laterodorsal tegmental nucleus ( Fig . 3D ) , but none were labelled in the parabrachial nucleus or locus coeruleus .

Finally , cortical labelling was observed in the olfactory bulb and piriform cortex ( Fig . 3A , B ) , which contained numerous labelled varicose axons , and in infralimbic and entorhinal cortex where lighter fiber labelling was evident .
Local connections within the SI and with other parts of the cholinergic basal forebrain
The neuropil immediately surrounding any PHA - L injection site in the SI contained numerous PHA - L - filled axonal swellings , indicating a moderately dense local terminal field ( Fig . 4A , B ) .

Occasionally , juxtapositions could be seen between such varicosities and the PHA - L - filled dendrite of a neuron that had taken up the lectin ( Fig . 4B ) , perhaps reflecting axodendritic synaptic contacts .

Axon terminals were also labelled in more distant parts of the SI ; indeed , wherever PHA - L deposits were placed in the SI , lectin - filled varicose axons stretched throughout its rostrocaudal extent .
Most labelled axon swellings in the SI appeared to represent en passant terminals , often lying along fibers that crossed into the amygdala , bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , or hypothalamus .
The nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band on one side of the brain is known to project to its contralatera1 counterpart ( Fuller et al . , 86 ) .
Consequently, the SI contralateral to that injected in cases RPSI1-3 was carefully examined.
Only a few labelled varicose fibers were found , suggesting , nonetheless , at least some interconnection between the SI on each side of the brain .
Larger or differently placed injections might well have revealed a denser projection .
The SI shares a striking feature , the presence of cholinergic perikarya , with the medial septum , nucleus of the diagonal band , and parts of the globus pallidus .
To what extent is the SI affiliated by direct connections with other components of the cholinergic basal forebrain?

From PHAL deposits in the SI , at least a few labelled varicose fibers could be traced dorsally along the lateral face of the internal capsule where many intrapallidal cholinergic cells are found ( Fig . lC , D ) or followed ventrally into the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band ( Figs . 1B , 2B ) .

In turn , the PHA - L deposit in case RPDB1, centered in the NHDB , filled several varicose axons in the SI ( Fig . 3A ) , although such labelling may have resulted in part from the involvement of the rostral SI in the injection site .
By contrast , there may be only a minor direct communication between the medial septum and nucleus of the vertical limb of the diagonal band on the one hand , and the SI on the other .
As noted above , PHA - L injections into the SI labelled almost no axons in the nucleus of the ventral limb of the diagonal band or the medial septum .
Similarly , no PHA - L - filled fibers were evident in the SI following an injection ( not shown ) involving these structures in turn .
The NHDB, however, does maintain a heavy projection to the rest of the diagonal band-medial septum continuum.
A profusion of labelled varicose fibers swept through the vertical limb of the diagonal band into the medial septum after injections of PHA - L into the NHDB .

This projection appears to be reciprocated : a deposit involving parts of the medial septum and ventral limb of the diagonal band filled many varicose axons in the most medial portion of the NHDB , and a few in more lateral parts of the nucleus.

Results.S: The cells of origin for SI projections
Brains with WGA - HRP deposits in the efferent targets of the SI provided additional evidence regarding the subdivision of the region .

TTE.S: For example , after tracer deposits in the central or basolateral nuclei ( RHBL2, RHCE2, Fig . 7 ) of the amygdala , the dorsal SI contained numerous retrogradely filled cells embedded in a dense band of axons that appeared to have transported WGA - HRP in the anterograde direction from the amygdala ( Fig . 5A ) .
Far fewer perikarya or fibers were labelled in the ventral SI .

A modest number of WGA - HRP - filled cells were also found in the ventral pallidum in cases RHBL2 and RHCE2, but both labelled cells and fibers were sparse in the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band .

By contrast , WGA - HRP injections that mainly involved the medial nucleus of the amygdala ( RHBM1, Fig . 7 ) , or a large amygdaloid region ventral to the central nucleus ( RHBMB , not shown ) , labelled many cells in the ventral SI but only a few in the dorsal division .
Again , WGA - HRP - filled perikarya lay among numerous anterogradely labelled axons that , in these cases , streamed through the anterior amygdaloid area and ventral SI ( Fig . 5B ) .
Additional labelled cells appeared in the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band , particularly in the caudal part of that structure .
WGA - HRP injections placed in progressively more caudal sites in the brainstem labelled an increasing proportion of cells in the dorsal SI as compared with the ventral division .
Thus , a large WGA - HRP deposit in the ventral tegmental area , spreading into the supramammillary area ( RHVT2, Fig . 7 ) , labelled cells throughout the SI ( Fig . 6A ) .
A tracer deposit involving the dorsal raphe nucleus and central gray ( RHDR1, Fig . 7 ) labelled cells in the SI that appeared slightly more numerous in the dorsal division ( Fig . 6B ) .

Finally , when WGA - HRP injections were centered either in the parabrachial nucleus CRHPB6, Fig . 7 ) or in the dorsomedial medulla , involving the nucleus of the solitary tract and the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus ( RHM1, Fig . 7 ) , the majority of labelled perikarya in the SI appeared in the dorsal division ( Fig . 6C ) .
Interestingly , a few such cells were evident even in the dorsalmost strip of the SI that is marked by enkephalin - immunoreactive woolly fibers .
No backfilled cells could be identified , however , in the GP or VP themselves , or in the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band .

Results.S: Participation of cholinergic cells in SI projections

The double - labelling procedure employed to reveal both WGA - HRP and choline acetyltransferase immunoreactivity slightly reduced the number of ChAT - immunoreactive cells that could be identified in the basal forebrain compared with control sections stained for ChAT alone .
By contrast, the technique used to demonstrate both WGAHRP and acetylcholinesterase activity did not appear to decrease the number of cells staining strongly for AChE.
In both instances , WGA - HRP was marked by a granular reaction product ( Fig . 4C , D ) that was blue - black in color .
ChAT immunoreactivity or strong AChE reactivity was evident as a smooth, midbrown background stain filling the cell soma and proximal dendrites (Fig. 4D).
The double - labelling procedures employed were sufficiently sensitive to reveal a major involvement of cholinergic cells in a given projection .

TTE.S: For example , after WGAHRP injections in the cortex or the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala , at least one - half to almost all of the retrogradely labelled cells in the SI could be identified as immunoreactive for ChAT or as strongly AChE positive .

( In the case of the basolateral nucleus , a few additional double labelled neurons were observed in the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and the medial segment of the central nucleus of the amygdala . )

One or two doublelabelled cells were also found in each 50 - pm tissue section through the SI following tracer injections centered in the medial nucleus of the amygdala ( RHBMl , Figs . 5, 7 ) or in the amygdaloid region ventral to the central nucleus ( case RHBMB , not shown ) , without spread into the basolateral nucleus .

WGA - HRP deposits involving the lateral hypothalamus , habenular nuclei , ventral tegmental area , peripeduncular area , dorsal raphe , central gray , or parabrachial nucleus backfilled many cells in the SI and / or adjacent basal forebrain regions , but none were strongly AChE positive or immunoreactive for ChAT .
Thus, no evidence was obtained that cholinergic cells contribute significantly to projections to the former sites from the SI, ventral pallidum, or diagonal band-septa1 continuum.
Ventral pallidal cells , unlike neurons in the SI , were also labelled after tracer injections in the nucleus accumbens .
None of these was seen to contain cholinergic markers.

In two cases , RHMDl and RHPN3, with WGA - HRP injections centered , respectively , in the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus , and in the substantia nigra , a few doublelabelled cells could be identified in the basal forebrain .
In case RHMDZ , one or two such cells appeared in the nuclei of the vertical and horizontal limbs of the diagonal band in each 5O - wm section through these structures .
In RHPN3, a comparable small number of cells staining for both WGAHRP and ChAT appeared in the globus pallidus and SI .
In both cases , the basal forebrain structures in question contained numerous WGA - HRP - labelled perikarya that were negative for ChAT .

Results.S: Levey and Hallanger and their colleagues ( Levey et al . , ' 87 ; Hallanger et al . , ' 87 ) have reported significant cholinergic projections to the reticular nucleus of the thalamus from basal forebrain districts that include the cholinergic cell - rich region of the GP .

It is possible that the injection site in case RHPN3 intruded upon the most caudal part of the reticular nucleus or some other caudal thalamic structure and that this accounts for the handful of double - labelled basal forebrain cells seen in this brain .

TTE.S: However , a WGA - HRP deposit of comparable size centered in the peripeduncular area ( RHPNZ ) should have involved the same caudal thalamic structures , if anything , to a greater extent ; yet none of the WGA - HRP - filled cells observed in the SI or GP in this case was also immunoreactive for ChAT .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
projections of the SI reciprocate its afferent connections
A principal finding of the present study is that the efferent projections of the SI largely reciprocate its afferent connections.
A second observation follows from the first, namely, that ventral and dorsal divisions can be distinguished in the SI on the basis of its efferent as well as afferent connections.
In no case was a PHA-L injection entirely confined to either the dorsal or the ventral SI.

However, a comparison of available PHA-L cases, together with findings from WGAHRP experiments, established that descending efferents that reach caudal to the mesodiencephalic border, including projections to the parabrachial nucleus and medulla (Schwaber et al., '82), arise primarily from the dorsal SI.

Among these target cell groups, the nucleus of the solitary tract, parabrachial nucleus, and dorsal raphe have been shown previously to innervate more heavily the dorsal division of the SI (Grove, '88).

Findings from both PHA-L and WGA-HRP experiments further indicate that the efferents of the dorsal and ventral SI are distributed preferentially in different regions of the hypothalamus and amygdala, reciprocating equally selective afferentation from these areas (Grove, '88).

In summary, the dorsal SI projects heavily to the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and to the lateral: basolateral, and central nuclei of the amygdala; it projects more sparsely to an amygdaloid region that lies ventral to the central nucleus and dorsal to the cortical nuclei.

This ventral amygdaloid district, however, which may include at least parts of the intraamygdaloid division of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (Paxinos and Watson, '86) and the basomedial nucleus (Krettek and Price, '78b; de Olmos et al., '85; Paxinos and Watson, '861, receives a heavy innervation from the ventral SI.
The ventral division of the SI also projects in at least moderate density to the medial nucleus, anterior amygdaloid area, and medial portions of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis.

In the hypothalamus, efferents from the dorsal SI are distributed most heavily over the lateral preoptic area, paraventricular nucleus, and certain parts of the lateral hypothalamus, prominently including the perifornical and caudolateral zones described previously (Grove, '88).
Projections from the ventral SI terminate most densely in the medial preoptic area and anterior hypothalamus.

At least light projections to the lateral preoptic area, lateral hypothalamus (including its most medial district), and the ventromedial and arcuate hypothalamic nuclei also arise from the ventral SI.
The dorsomedial and posterior hypothalamus seem to be innervated by both divisions of the SI but perhaps more heavily by the ventral SI.

Widespread projections from the SI to the hypothalamus, with a similar overall pattern to that reported here, were previously noted by Mogenson et al. ('851, who, however, did not describe differences between the projections of dorsal and ventral parts of the SI.
Within the thalamus, some divergence from the principle of reciprocal connections is apparent.
Findings described in a previous report (Grove, '88) suggest that the SI receives innervation from the paratenial, paraventricular, central medial, rhomboid and reuniens nuclei of the thalamus.
Present observations indicate that the SI also projects to this group of midline thalamic nuclei.
However, the SI additionally innervates the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus and the reticular nucleus of the thalamus, neither of which appears to send efferents to the SI (Grove, '88).

In its connection with the mediodorsal nucleus the SI resembles the amygdala, which also maintains a projection to the mediodorsal nucleus that is not reciprocated (Krettek and Price, '78a; Ottersen and Ben-Ari, '79).

The projection to the reticular nucleus of the thalamus represents part of a cholinergic and noncholinergic innervation of that nucleus reported to arise from several basal forebrain regions, including the SI (Hallanger et al., '87; Levey et al., '87).

The present PHA-L experiments provided no evidence that the projection to the SI and the cholinergic cell-rich region of the globus pallidus that arises from a continuum of cells in the parvocellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus of the thalamus and peripeduncular area (Jones et al., '76; Grove, '88) is returned in comparably high volume.

A WGA-HRP injection involving the PPA and adjacent substantia nigra (case RHPN2) labelled a few cells in the 2Note, however, that no evidence was obtained in a previous WGA-HRP study (Grove, '88) that the lateral nucleus of the amyg dala innervates the SI.
globus pallidus, SI, and the medial part of the central nucleus of the amygdala.

However, many more cells were labelled, particularly in the GP and central nucleus, after an injection of comparable size restricted to the lateral third of the substantia nigra (case RHPN3), suggesting that this nucleus may be the primary target.

The central nucleus of the amygdala has been reported previously to project to both the lateral part of the substantia nigra and the peripeduncular nucleus (Krettek and Price, 78a; Price and Amaral, 81).
The cortical projections of the SI, however, again appear to reciprocate closely the afferent connections of the region.
Findings described elsewhere (Grove, 88) indicate that prominent cortical afferents to the SI arise from medial prefrontal, insular, perirhinal and entorhinal cortices.

Efferents from at least the mid-rostrocaudal part of the SI that was injected with PHA-L in cases RPSI2 and RPSI3 terminate most heavily in the same cortical areas as well as innervating piriform cortex and the main and accessory olfactory bulbs.
Projections to the cortex from the SI also display some dorsal to ventral organization.
That is, efferents from the ventral SI that were labelled in the present study appeared to be distributed preferentially in the most ventrally placed cortices, namely, piriform and entorhinal cortex.

The rough dorsal-to-ventral organization of cortical projections from the SI also appears to apply to some extent to efferents from the ventrally contiguous nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band and the dorsally adjacent, cholinergic cell-rich region of the globus pallidus.
Further, the organization may have the effect of associating these regions with cortices that are connectionally and functionally appropriate.

Thus, the PHA-L deposit in NHDB in case RPDBl produced heavy varicose fiber labelling in the amygdaloid nuclei defined by Scalia and Winans ( 75) as components of the olfactory amygdala, as well as in the olfactory bulb and primary olfactory cortex.

The PHA-L injection in case RPSI3 densely labelled fibers in widespread areas of the amygdala, prominently including the basolateral and lateral nuclei, and, as will be discussed further below, in cortical areas that are themselves in direct contact with the basolateral amygdaloid group in the rat (Krettek and Price, 77b; Turner and Zimmer, 84; and for review, see de Olmos et al., 85).
Finally, the cholinergic cell-rich region of the globus pallidus contains relatively few cells that innervate the amygdala, and is invaded by only sparse amygdalofugal fibers.

Several studies in which anterograde tracers have been placed in this region, dorsal to the SI injection sites described in the present study, have indicated substantial projections to cortices on the convexity of the hemisphere (Saper, 84; Haber et al., 85; Luiten et al., 85, 87) that have not been reported in the rat to be heavily connected with the amygdala.
(For a review of corticoamygdaloid relations in the rat, see de Olmos et al., 85.)
Pallidal-type cells may contribute to projections from the SI
Tissue with features that are characteristic of the neuropi1 of the ventral pallidum and globus pallidus appears to overflow into part, though not all, of the adjacent dorsal division of the SI.

That is, the dorsalmost portion of the region that can be defined as substantia innominata by the passage of a high volume of fibers belonging to the ansa peduncularis is also invaded by enkephalin-immunoreactive woolly fibers (Grove, 88), a configuration of axon terminals characteristic of the striatopallidal projection (Haber and Elde, 81; Switzer et al., 82; Haber and Nauta, 83).

In addition, this part of the SI maintains reciprocal connections with the fundus of the striatum (present study; Grove, These observations raise questions that are pertinent to any account of the SI and its connections, although it is important to emphasize that they do not concern the entire dorsal division of the SI as defined here-only the most dorsal strip that displays pallidal features.
Should this strip of the SI properly be viewed as an extension of the globus pallidus, or, at least, as mixed with pallidal tissue?
If so, which of the efferents of the SI demonstrated in the present study might be expected to represent the projections of pallidal cells?
At present the answers to these questions are unclear.
The dorsalmost part of the SI is a complex tissue that displays both pallidal and nonpallidal attributes.
Considering these in turn: 1.
The ENK-IR woolly fiber configuration appears when nonimmunoreactive dendrites or cell bodies are densely invested with ENK-IR axon terminals.

Thus, their presence in the dorsalmost SI strongly suggests the presence of a category of cell that is common in the ventral pallidum and globus pallidus, whose dendritic and somatic surface is studded with numerous striatofugal axon terminals (Fox et al., 74; Heimer and Wilson, 75; Heimer et al., 87; Zahm et al., 87).
It should be noted that such cells appear to be projection neurons in the ventral pallidum (Zahm et al., 87).

However, the ENK-IR axons that compose the woolly fibers in the SI have not been directly shown to originate from the striatum as they have in the VP and GP (Zaborszky et al., 82; Haber and Nauta, 83), and such axons could originate from other structures (see Grove, 88).

Ultimately, whether pallidal-type cells are present in the dorsal SI and what their connections may be will be determined only by studies similar to those of the VP cited above in which the source of ENK-IR axons was determined (Zaborszky et al., 82; Haber and Nauta, 83) and the connections and morphological features of cells were examined in the light and electron microscope (Fox et al., 74; Heimer and Wilson, 75; Heimer et al., 87; Zahm et al., 87).
The tissue that makes up the dorsalmost strip of the SI can also be differentiated histochemically from the adjacent ventral pallidum and globus pallidus.
Whereas the VP and GP display a patchy appearance in Timm-stained material, the whole of the SI is characterized by modest, even staining (de Olmos et al., 85).

Further, the entire dorsal division of the SI is distinguished by the selective termination of fibers immunoreactive for tyrosine hydroxylase (Grove, 88) and by the argyrophilia it exhibits in cupric-silver preparations (de Olmos, 72; de Olmos et al., 85).
At present it seems most likely that the dorsalmost part of the SI is a heterogeneous tissue, containing several intermingled cell populations.
Such cell groups would appear to include not only cholinergic and noncholinergic cells that innervate the cortex and amygdala but also other cell types characteristic of the SI as a whole.

For example, WGA-HRP deposits involving the parabrachial nucleus or the nucleus of the solitary tract and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus backfill many cells in the dorsal SI, including a few in the part invaded by ENK-IR woolly fibers.

Given the visceroceptive and visceromotor associations of the parabrachial nucleus and dorsomedial medulla, these structures appear improbable targets of pallidal cells, at least given our present conception of the role of the globus pallidus in somatomotor function.

It is tempting to assume that the projections from the dorsal SI to the amygdala, diencephalon, midbrain, and pons, because they appear to be part of a general system of topographically organized connections linking the two subdivisions of the SI to a diversity of cell groups lying along the ansa peduncularis and medial forebrain bundle, must also arise entirely from cells characteristic of the SI as a whole.

Certainly, both WGA-HRP and PHA-L experiments indicate that such projections arise fiom cells in that part of the dorsal SI division that exhibits no pallidal features, and thus, at least in that region, from cells typical of the SI.

However, the ansa peduncularis and medial forebrain bundle are common routes for efferents from several basal forebrain structures, including the nucleus accumbens (Nauta et al., '78) and the region here called ventral pallidum (Swanson et al., '84; Haber et al., '85).
All of these distribute efferents over an apparently similar set of hypothalamic and midbrain targets.
Fibers from the ventral pallidum continue into the pons, innervating the pedunculopontine nucleus (Swanson et al., '84; Haber et al., '85), which lies just rostral to the parabrachial nucleus.
Thus, some fiber contingents arising from the dorsalmost SI may receive contributions from both pallidal-type cells and neurons more characteristic of the entire SI.
Further work will be needed to determine if this is so and whether efferents arising from different cell types might distribute over slightly different targets along the route of the AP and MFB.
The efferent projections of the SI resemble those of the amygdala

The subcortical projections of the dorsal SI determined in the present study are reminiscent of those previously reported for the central nucleus of the amygdala and the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (Krettek and Price, '78a; Price, '81; Price and Amaral, '81; Holstege et al., '85).
Similarly, the efferent connections of the ventral SI resemble those of the medial amygdaloid nucleus (Krettek and Price, '78a).

Available for direct comparison with the cases described in the present study were several others, previously described (Grove, '88) in which PHA-L had been deposited adjacent to the SI in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis or amygdala.

Examination of these cases demonstrated that the distribution of PHA-L-filled fibers in subcortical structures is indeed strikingly similar whether the lectin injection is placed in a division of the SI itself or in contiguous parts of the BNS or amygdala.

Specifically, PHA-L injections involving the lateral BNS (RPGP4, RPBNSB), dorsal SI (RPSI1 and RPSI3), or central nucleus of the amygdala (RPAA1, RPACe8) (see Fig. 1 and Grove, '88, Figs. 8,9) label axons in the same set of subcortical forebrain structures: the lateral BNS, dorsal SI, central nucleus of the amygdala, lateral preoptic area, paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus, perifornical and caudolateral zones of the lateral hypothalamus, dorsomedial and posterior hypothalamus, and midline thalamic cell groups, prominently including the medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus.
The lateral nucleus of the amygdala is also innervated by the lateral BNS as well as by the dorsal SI.

Observations from WGA-HRP experiments additionally indicate that projections to the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala arise not only from the dorsal SI but also from a few cholinergic and noncholinergic cells in the lateral BNS and medial part of the central nucleus.

Similarly, when PHA-L injection sites involve the medial portion of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (RPBNSB), ventral SI (RPSI1 and 2), rostral part of the medial nucleus of the amygdala (RPABl), or rostral part of the amygdaloid region ventral to the central nucleus (RPBMl), axons are labelled in each of the other regions, as well as in the medial and lateral preoptic areas, anterior hypothalamus, medialmost district of the lateral hypothalamus, dorsomedial and posterior hypothalamus, and mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus (see Grove, '88, Figs. 8, 9, and text).

The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus, which receives a prominent projection from the medial nucleus (Krettek and Price, '78a, Price, '811, is also at least lightly innervated by the ventral SI.

Finally, moderately dense fiber labelling appears caudal to the diencephalon in a distribution similar to that shown in Figure 1G-I (case RPSI3) whenever the lateral BNS, dorsal SI, or central nucleus of the amygdala are involved in the PHA-L injection site (cases RPSI1, RPGP4, RPBNSB, RPAA1, and RPACe8).
Some differences appear in the density and topography of subcortical projections from different parts of the two BNSSI-amygdala continua.
For example, as PHA-L injections are placed more rostromedially in the two continua, progressively denser fiber labelling appears in many parts of the hypothalamus.
Heavier and more widespread axon labelling appears in the amygdala when PHA-L deposits are placed in the SI than when deposits are made in the BNS or in the central nucleus of the amygdala.
A few differences appear also in projections to the brainstem, reflecting a rostrocaudal ordering of efferents.

For example, the lateral BNS projects most heavily to a more rostral part of the parabrachial nucleus than does the dorsal SI, although the same parabrachial subnuclei (Fulwiler and Saper, '84) appear to be involved.

Previous studies have established two distinctive efferent pathways leading to a different set of subcortical structures from the central nucleus on one hand, and a ventromedial region of the amygdala, prominently including the medial nucleus, on the other (Krettek and Price, '78a; Price, '81; Price and Amaral, '81; de Olmos et al., '85).

Although other amygdaloid nuclei, including the basolateral and basomedial nuclei, maintain at least modest projections to the hypothalamus and other subcortical sites, the central and medial nuclei appear to represent output "staging" areas of the amygdala, receiving projections from other amygdaloid nuclei (Krettek and Price, '78b; Aggleton, '85) and projecting heavily to diencephalic and caudal brainstem structures (Krettek and Price, '78a; Price, '81).

Earlier investigations have demonstrated strong similarities between the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis and the medial part of the central amygdaloid nucleus in their projections to brainstem structures (Schwaber et al., '82; Holstege et al., '85).

Further, a continuum of cells stretching between these two structures through the SI has been labelled by retrograde tracer injections involving the parabrachial nucleus, the nucleus of the solitary tract and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus, or the nucleus raphe magnus and adjoining midline reticular formation (Schwaber et al., '82; Holstege et al., '85).

Findings from the present study augment these observations and establish that the two "staging areas" of the amygdala extend from the medial and central nuclei into, respectively, the ventral and dorsal SI and medial and lateral BNS.
The most striking difference between the efferent connections of the SI and immediately adjacent parts of the amygdala and BNS is that the SI projects widely to the cortex.
Only sparse fibers were labelled in piriform and insular cortices in case RPSI1, which contained a PHA-L deposit in the transitional area between the SI and bed nucleus of the stria terminalis.
No cortical labelling followed injections into the BNS itself or the central nucleus of the amygdala.
PHA-L deposits in the rostroventromedial amygdala labelled fibers only in piriform cortex (Grove, '88, Fig. 9).

However, consistent with previous reports (Krettek and Price, '77b; for review, see de Olmos et al., '851, a PHA-L injection into the basolateral nucleus (case RPBL2, Grove, '88, Fig. 9), which is interconnected with the central nucleus, dorsal SI, and lateral BNS, labelled varicose fibers in the medial prefrontal, agranular insular, piriform, perirhinal, and entorhinal cortices.
Of those cortical areas that contained PHA-L-filled varicose axons in case RPSI3, only granular insular cortex appeared free of labelled fibers.
Thus, the cortical projections of at least the midcaudal portion of the SI also closely resemble those of a neighboring amygdaloid nucleus.
Cholinergic projections to the amygdala and cortex may be integrated into the efferent circuitry of the SI

It has been proposed that the population of cholinergic cells that reaches from the medial septum and the nucleus of the diagonal band through the SI and into the caudal globus pallidus may form a single anatomical and functional entity (Schwaber et al., '87).

Thus, it is plausible that cholinergic neurons invade the SI but are not part of it, maintaining afferent and efferent connections that are typical of the cholinergic cell continuum but wholly unrelated to those of other SI cells.
Several observations from the present pair of studies appear pertinent to this issue.

Findings reported by Grove ('88) suggested that the cholinergic cell group in the SI (like other cells in the region) may receive some innervation from the hypothalamus, peripeduncular area, ventral tegmental area, and dorsal raphe nucleus.

Nonetheless, the present study provides no evidence that the cholinergic cells of the SI innervate these areas in return or contribute significantly to any extrinsic projections of the SI other than those previously described to the cortex, basolateral nucleus of the amygdala, and reticular nucleus of the thalamus.
Some intrinsic connections within the SI may arise, however, from local cholinergic neurons.

A procedure developed for labelling cholinergic fibers has demonstrated ChATimmunoreactive axonal varicosities, probably representing synaptic terminals, in the SI and ventromedial globus pallidus (this study).
ChAT-IR synaptic boutons have previously been observed in the electron microscope in the ventral pallidum (Zaborszky et al., '86b) and globus pallidus (Ingham, personal communication).
Both Ingham (personal communication) and Zaborszky et al. ('86b) noted that synaptic contacts were formed between ChAT-IR boutons and nonimmunoreactive elements.
If noncholinergic projection neurons are among those innervated, cholinergic cells in the SI could have a significant influence over a range of subcortical SI projections.
A more fundamental observation is that the cholinergic projections that arise from cells within the SI appear to fit with the overall character of SI connections.
Both the afferents and efferents of the region associate it strongly with much of the amygdala and with structures that are themselves directly connected with the amygdala.

Thus, the cholinergic (and non-cholinergic) projection from the SI to the basolateral amygdaloid nucleus is only part of a voluminous system of SI efferents that distributes over most of the amygdala (present study; Russchen, '82; Aggleton et al., '87).
It is notable, too, that the cholinergic cells innervating the basolateral nucleus are mainly confined to the dorsal division of the SI, obeying the general topography of SI-amygdala connections.
The projections from cholinergic cells in the SI to the cortex may also conform to the pattern.
Medial prefrontal, insular, perirhinal, entorhinal, and piriform cortices seem to receive a preferentially heavy innervation from the SI, most of which is likely to be cholinergic (Rye et al., '84).

The same cortical areas have been reported to be directly interconnected with the "basolateral" amygdaloid group in the rat (Krettek and Price, '77b; Turner and Zimmer, '84; and for review, see de Olmos et al., '85).

More generally, cholinergic corticopetal projections may be only one element of a set of direct and indirect pathwa;ys leading from the SI to the cortical mantle, which appear to converge upon similar cortical sites.
Saper ('85) has d.escribed projections to the cortex arising from scattered cel Is in the lateral hypothalamus.
In particular, cells in the caudolateral zone of the LH, which is reciprocally connected with the dorsal SI, innervate insular and medial prefrontal cortex.
The medial part of the mediodorsal nucleus, which receives a projection from noncholinergic SI neurons, innervates rostra1 insular cortex (Krettek and Price, '77a).

Finally, the medial division of the parabrachial nucleus, also reciprocally connected with the SI, projects to ventral infralimbic cortex and both anterior and posterior granular and agranular insular cortex (Saper and Loewy, '80; Saper, %2; Fulwiler and Saper, '84).

Further study is needed to answer questions about the circuitry that might coordinate these cortical infiuences-whether, for example, SI efferents synapse directly on cortically projecting neurons in the amyg dala, lateral hypothalamus, thalamus, or parabrachial nucleus.
In summary, the findings of the present study support three generalizations that may be of use in designing behavioral and physiological studies of the SI.
Second, the SI is organized into a ventral and a dorsal division, suggesting functional heterogeneity.
Swh an organization is indicated by both the afferent and efferent connections of the SI, as well as by histochemical features (de Olmos, '72; de Olmos et al., '85; Grove, '88; present study).

Finally, although the cholinergic neurons in the SI belong to a cell type that is dispersed rather widely in the basal forebrain, those within the SI may be integrated into the overall afferent and efferent circuitry of the region, and thus into whatever functional roles the SI may subserve.
